case_name: Godhra Electricity Co. Ltd. v. Gujarat State Electricity Board

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2016 of 1973 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated 15th/16th October 1973 of the Gujarat High Court in Spl. Civil Appls. No. 1752 of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2016 of 1973. Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment and order dated the 15th/16th October, 1973 of the Gujarat High Court in Spl. Civil Apples. No. 1752 of 1972.

facts.text: Appellants filed a writ petition before the High Court of Gujarat challenging the validity of a notification issued by the Gujarat State Electricity Board dated November 8, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed a writ petition before the High Court of Gujarat challenging the validity of a numberice issued by the Gujarat State Electricity Board, respondent No. 2, dated November 8, 1971, whereby respondent No. 2 purported to exercise the option of purchasing the electrical undertaking of appellant No. 1 under S. 6 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910  hereinafter referred to as the Act  and for a declaration that the provisions of sections 6, 7 and 7A of the Act are ultra vires Articles 14, 19 1   f , 19 1   g  and 31 of the Constitution.

facts.text: The High Court dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the petition and this appeal, by certificate, is against that judgment.

facts.text: Government of the Province of Bombay granted a licence by notification dated November 16, 1922 under S. 3 of the Act known as the Godhra Electric Licence, 1922 in favour of Lady Sulochana Chinubhai and Company, Ahmedabad.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of the Province of Bombay granted a licence by numberification dated November 16, 1922, under S. 3 of the Act known as the Godhra Electric Licence, 1922 in favour of Lady Sulochana Chinubhai and Company, Ahmedabad.

facts.text: The licence was signed on November 17, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The licence was signed on November 17, 1922 and the numberification granting it was published in the Bombay Government Gazette dated November 23, 1922

facts.text: Notification granting the licence was published in the Bombay Government Gazette dated November 23, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The licence was signed on November 17, 1922 and the numberification granting it was published in the Bombay Government Gazette dated November 23, 1922 The licence was transferred to the ist appellant-company viz., the Godhra Electricity Co. Ltd.

facts.text: The licence was transferred to the 1st appellant-company, the Godhra Electricity Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The licence was transferred to the ist appellant-company viz., the Godhra Electricity Co. Ltd. The licence was for a period of 50 years initially from its companymencement.

facts.text: The licence was for a period of 50 years initially from its commencement.

anchor.surface_text: The licence was for a period of 50 years initially from its companymencement. The initial period of 50 years, according to the respondents, was to expire on the midnight intervening between the 15th and 16th November, 1972.

facts.text: According to respondents, the initial period of 50 years was to expire on the midnight intervening between 15th and 16th November, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The initial period of 50 years, according to the respondents, was to expire on the midnight intervening between the 15th and 16th November, 1972. The second respondent exercised the option to purchase the undertaking of the 1st appellant companypany by a numberice dated November 8, 1971, under s. 6 1  of the Act by calling upon the appellants to sell the undertaking to it on the midnight intervening between the 15th and 16th of November, 1972.

facts.text: Second respondent exercised option to purchase the undertaking of 1st appellant by notice dated November 8, 1971 under s.6(1) of the Act, requiring sale on midnight intervening 15th and 16th November, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent exercised the option to purchase the undertaking of the 1st appellant companypany by a numberice dated November 8, 1971, under s. 6 1  of the Act by calling upon the appellants to sell the undertaking to it on the midnight intervening between the 15th and 16th of November, 1972. Thereafter. the Government of Gujarat issued a numberification under rule 115 2  of the Defence of India Rules taking over the management of the undertaking on November 18.1973.

facts.text: Government of Gujarat issued notification under rule 115 of Defence of India Rules taking over management of the undertaking on November 18, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter. the Government of Gujarat issued a numberification under rule 115 2  of the Defence of India Rules taking over the management of the undertaking on November 18.1973. On December 21, 1973 of the State Government handed over the undertaking to the 2nd respondent.

facts.text: State Government handed over the undertaking to the 2nd respondent on December 21, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: On December 21, 1973 of the State Government handed over the undertaking to the 2nd respondent. Before we proceed further, it would be companyvenient at this stage to numbere the amendment mad in the Act by Act 32 of 1959.

facts.text: Indian Electricity Act amended by Act 32 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Before we proceed further, it would be companyvenient at this stage to numbere the amendment mad in the Act by Act 32 of 1959.

facts.text: Appellants contended that date of commencement of licence was date of publication in Gazette, November 23, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, we are companycerned with two companytentions raised by the appellants. They are, that the date of the companymencement of the licence was the date on which the numberification granting the licence was published in the Bombay Gazette, viz., November 23, 1922

facts.text: Notice specified expiry of period as November 15, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, the numberice specified the date of the expiry of the period as November 15, 1972. So, the question is, whether the period of 50 years expired on November 15, 1972,

facts.text: Clause 2(e) of the licence defines commencement as date of notification by Government of Bombay in Gazette that licence has been granted.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 2 e  of the licence says The date of the numberification by the Government of Bombay in the Bombay Government Gazette that this licence has been granted is in this licence referred to as the companymencement of this licence .

facts.text: Rule 18 of Indian Electricity Rules, 1922 states that date of notification under Rule 17 shall be deemed date of commencement of licence.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 17 of the Indian Electricity Rules, 1922, provides for publication of the licence in the local official gazette to numberify that it has been granted. Rule 18 states that the date of the numberification under Rule 17 shall be deemed to be the date of the companymencement of the licence.

facts.text: Court held that date of commencement of licence was November 16, 1922, the date of notification granting the licence.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, the date of the numberification granting the licence was November 16, 1922. There can, therefore, be numberdoubt that the date of companymencement of the licence was November 16, 1922.

facts.text: Appellants and intervener contended that licence could not be granted before signing on November 17, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: But companynsel for the appellants as well as the intervener companytended that it is impossible to imagine that a licence companyld be granted without the licenser signing the licence and as the licence bears the date November 17, 1922 and was signed only on that day,

facts.text: Court held that clause 2(e) to be read with Rule 18, making notification date the commencement date even if anterior to signing.

anchor.surface_text: We have to read clause 2 e  of the licence in the light of the provisions of r. 18. Therefore, there is numberhing strange in making the date of the numberification in the Gazette that the licence has been granted, though anterior in point of time to the date of signing the licence, as the date of companymencement of the licence.

facts.text: Licence subsequently amended, referring to notification dated 16th November 1922 published 23rd November 1922.

anchor.surface_text: That amendment reads that the following amendment be made in the fourth annexure to the Godhra Electric Licence, 1922, which was granted in Government numberification No. 177, dated 16th November, 1922, and published at pages 2652 to 2656 of Part I of the Bombay Government Gazette dated 23rd November 1922

facts.text: Court held section 6(6) of the Act violates Articles 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: We hold that S. 6 6  violates the fundamental right under Art. 19 1  g  and 19 1  f  of the 2nd appellant.

facts.text: There was no valid purchase of the undertaking and taking delivery was unlawful.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that there was numbervalid purchase of the undertaking and that taking delivery of the undertaking was unlawful.

facts.text: Court directed State Electricity Board to redeliver the undertaking to the licensee.

anchor.surface_text: The State Electricity Board is directed to redeliver the undertaking to the licensee. We set aside the judgment under appeal and allow the appeal to the extent indicated but, in the circumstances, without any order as to companyts.

issues.text: Whether the notice dated November 8, 1971 issued by respondent No. 2 purportedly exercising the option to purchase under S. 6 of the Act is valid?

anchor.surface_text: challenging the validity of a numberice issued by the Gujarat State Electricity Board, respondent No. 2, dated November 8, 1971, whereby respondent No. 2 purported to exercise the option of purchasing the electrical undertaking of appellant No. 1 under S. 6 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910  hereinafter referred

issues.text: Whether sections 6, 7 and 7A of the Act are ultra vires Articles 14, 19(1)(f), 19(1)(g) and 31 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: sections 6, 7 and 7A of the Act are ultra vires Articles 14, 19 1   f , 19 1   g  and 31 of the Constitution. The High Court dismissed the petition and this appeal, by certificate, is against that judgment.

issues.text: Whether the date of commencement of the licence was the publication date (November 23, 1922) or the notification date (November 16, 1922), such that the 50 years period expired on midnight intervening 15th/16th November 1972?

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, we are concerned with two contentions raised by the appellants. They are, that the date of the commencement of the licence was the date on which the notification granting the licence was published in the Bombay Gazette, viz., November 23, 1922 and not the date of the notification granting the licence i.e., November 16, 1922, and, therefore, the 50 years period did number expire on the midnight intervening between the 15th and 16th November, 1972 and so, the numberice requiring the licensee to sell the undertaking on the expiryof the period, namely, 15h November, 1972 was bad

issues.text: Whether sub-section (6) of S. 6 of the Act is violative of the fundamental rights under Articles 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g)?

anchor.surface_text: The point then for companysideration is whether s. 6 6  of the Act is violative of the fundamental right under Articles 19 1   f  and 19 1   g . Section 6 6  reads Where a numberice exercising the option of purchasing the undertaking has been served upon the licensee under this section,

issues.text: Whether the arbitrator functioning under S. 7A has power to award interest on the purchase price?

anchor.surface_text: But the question is whether the arbitrator has power under the Act to award interest on the purchase price. In Toronto City Corporation v. Toronto Railway Corporation 2 , the Privy Council held that the general rule under which a purchaser who takes possession is charged with interest on his purchase money from that time until it is paid was well established,

issues.text: Whether the 2nd appellant as shareholder and Managing Director has standing to challenge violation of fundamental rights under Art. 19(1)(f) and (g)?

anchor.surface_text: We hold that S. 6 6  violates the fundamental right under Art. 19 1  g  and 19 1  f  of the 2nd appellant. The undertaking, numberdoubt, belonged to the 1st appellant, a companyporation. Not being a citizen, it has numberfundamental right under Art. 19. The 2nd appellant is a shareholder and the Managing Director of the Company. If his right to carry on the business through the agency of the Company is taken away or abridged,

arguments.claim: The date of the commencement of the licence was the date on which the notification granting the licence was published in the Bombay Gazette, viz., November 23, 1922

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, we are concerned with two contentions raised by the appellants. They are, that the date of the commencement of the licence was the date on which the notification granting the licence was published in the Bombay Gazette, viz., November 23, 1922 and not the date of the notification granting the licence i.e., November 16, 1922, and, therefore, the 50 years period did not expire

arguments.court_reasoning: Date of notification granting the licence was November 16, 1922 per clause 2(e) and rule 18

arguments.claim: The notice exercising the option to purchase must strictly conform to requirements of S.6(1) otherwise ineffective

anchor.surface_text: The ruling of this Court make it clear that when the State or the State Electricity Board exercises its statutory option to purchase the undertaking of a licensee, it must in all respects conform strictly to the requirements of S. 6 1  and that the failure to conform to any one of them would render the exercise of the option ineffective  see Gujarat Electricity Board v. Shantilal R. Desai

arguments.claim: The notice specified the date of the expiry of the period as November 15, 1972 correctly as period expired then

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, the notice specified the date of the expiry of the period as November 15, 1972. So, the question is, whether the period of 50 years expired on November 15, 1972, Clause 2 e  of the licence says The date of the notification by the Government of Bombay in the Bombay Government Gazette that this licence has been granted is in this licence referred to as the commencement of this licence .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: antilal R. Desai 1  and Gujarat Elec- tricity Board v. Girdharlal Motilal and Another .  2

arguments.claim: Provisions of sections 6, 7 and 7A of the Act are ultra vires Articles 14, 19(1)(f), 19(1)(g) and 31

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed a writ petition before the High Court of Gujarat challenging the validity of a notice issued by the Gujarat State Electricity Board, respondent No. 2, dated November 8, 1971, whereby respondent No. 2 purported to exercise the option of purchasing the electrical undertaking of appellant No. 1 under S. 6 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910  hereinafter referred to as the Act  and for a declaration that the provisions of sections 6, 7 and 7A

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Amrao Singh, 1961 3 S. C. R. 676.  2  1925 A. C. 177 at pp. 193-194. Unreported

arguments.claim: S.6(6) provision postponing payment of purchase price till after arbitrator determination is unreasonable restriction on Art.19(1)(g) and violative of Art.19(1)(f)

anchor.surface_text: The appellants submitted that the provision of S. 6 6  which postpones the payment of the purchase price till after the determination, of the quantum of the purchase price by the arbitrator is an unreasonable restriction upon the fundamental right of citizens to carry on business under Article 19  1   g  and also violative of their fundamental right under Article 19 1   f . They submitted that before the amendment in 1959 to the Act,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Amrao Singh, 1961 3 S. C. R. 676.  2  1925 A. C. 177 at pp. 193-194. Unreported

arguments.court_reasoning: Deprives licensee of undertaking without payment or interest compensation unreasonable

arguments.claim: Appellants had no right to carry on business after valid notice exercising option

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Solicitor General, on the other hand, submitted that the appellants had no right to carry on the business when the Board chose to exercise the option to purchase the undertaking. at the expiry of the period. The argument was that when a valid notice to exercise the option to purchase the undertaking has been served on the licensee, the licensee thereafter has no right to carry on the business of supplying electricity

court_response_anchor.surface_text: o take delivery of the undertaking without payment of the purchase price.  1  see Satinder Singh v. Amrao Singh, 1961 3 S. C. R. 676.  2  1925 A. C. 1

arguments.court_reasoning: No valid purchase or delivery without payment or interest; licence continues until valid sale

arguments.claim: Obligation to pay interest on purchase price from delivery date is implicit in s.7A or arbitrator bound under common law to award it

anchor.surface_text: He also submitted- that the obligation to pay interest on the purchase price from the date of the delivery of the undertaking up to the date of its payment is-implicit in s, 7A  or at any rate the arbitrator functioning under that section is bound, under the common law of the land to award interest for the period during which the arbitration proceedings were pending.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y without payment of the purchase price would number be reasonable. But, to deprive the licensee of his undertaking without payment of the purchase pr

arguments.court_reasoning: Arbitrator under s.7A has no power to award interest; only market value at time of purchase/delivery

arguments.claim: Arbitrator under s.7A has no power to award interest on purchase price

anchor.surface_text: But the question is whether the arbitrator has power under the Act to award interest on the purchase price. In Toronto City Corporation v. Toronto Railway Corporation 2 , the Privy Council held that the general rule under which a purchaser who takes possession is charged with interest on his purchase money from that time until it is paid was well established,

arguments.claim: 2nd appellant as shareholder and Managing Director has fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(f),(g) impaired by S.6(6)

anchor.surface_text: We hold that S. 6 6  violates the fundamental right under Art. 19 1  g  and 19 1  f  of the 2nd appellant. The undertaking, no doubt, belonged to the 1st appellant, a corporation. Not being a citizen, it has no fundamental right under Art. 19. The 2nd appellant is a shareholder and the Managing Director of the Company.

arguments.court_reasoning: Cites R.C. Cooper and Bennett Coleman on shareholder standing when company rights impaired

arguments.claim: Clause 2(e) of licence to be read in harmony with rule 18 of Electricity Rules

anchor.surface_text: We have to read clause 2 e  of the licence in the light of the provisions of r. 18. Therefore, there is nothing strange in making the date of the notification in the Gazette that the licence has been granted, though anterior in point of time to the date of signing the licence, as the date of commencement of the licence.

arguments.claim: Subsequent interpreting statements and conduct admissible for ambiguous documents

anchor.surface_text: The question whether subsequent interpreting statement made by parties to a written instrument is admissible in evidence to construe the written instrument is not free from doubt.

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguishes English precedents, prefers practical interpretation allowing subsequent conduct for latent ambiguity

holdings.text: The date of commencement of the licence was November 16, 1922, the date of the notification granting the licence.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, the date of the notification granting the licence was November 16, 1922. There can, therefore, be no doubt that the date of commencement of the licence was November 16, 1922.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 2(e) of licence defines commencement as date of notification in Gazette that licence granted; Rule 18 deems date of notification under Rule 17 as commencement date.

holdings.text: Clause 2(e) must be read in light of Rule 18 such that notification date is commencement even if anterior to signing date.

anchor.surface_text: We have to read clause 2 e  of the licence in the light of the provisions of r. 18. Therefore, there is nothing strange in making the date of the notification in the Gazette that the licence has been granted, though anterior in point of time to the date of signing the licence, as the date of commencement of the licence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading of licence clause with Electricity Rules 1922; nothing strange in deeming notification date as commencement prior to signing.

holdings.text: Exercise of option under S.6(1) requires strict compliance with all requirements including correct expiry date; notice valid as expiry correctly specified as November 15, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The ruling of this Court make it clear that when the State or the State Electricity Board exercises its statutory option to purchase the undertaking of a licensee, it must in all respects conform strictly to the requirements of S. 6 1  and that the failure to conform to any one of them would render the exercise of the option ineffective  see Gujarat Electricity Board v. Shantilal R. Desai

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent requires strict compliance; expiry date correct per licence commencement on Nov 16, 1922 leading to expiry midnight Nov 15/16, 1972.

holdings.text: Arbitrator under S.7A has no power to award interest on purchase price.

anchor.surface_text: But the question is whether the arbitrator has power under the Act to award interest on the purchase price. In Toronto City Corporation v. Toronto Railway Corporation 2 , the Privy Council held that the general rule under which a purchaser who takes possession is charged with interest on his purchase money from that time until it is paid was well established,

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.7A limits arbitrator to market value at purchase/delivery time; no provision for interest; precedents confirm arbitrator cannot award interest beyond statutory mandate.

holdings.text: S.6(6) violates fundamental rights under Articles 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g) of the 2nd appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that S. 6 6  violates the fundamental right under Art. 19 1  g  and 19 1  f  of the 2nd appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requires delivery without payment or interest compensation; unreasonable restriction as deprives licensee of undertaking and business without adequate remedy; arbitrator cannot award interest.

holdings.text: 2nd appellant as shareholder and Managing Director has standing to challenge S.6(6) under Articles 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: We hold that S. 6 6  violates the fundamental right under Art. 19 1  g  and 19 1  f  of the 2nd appellant. The undertaking, no doubt, belonged to the 1st appellant, a corporation. Not being a citizen, it has no fundamental right under Art. 19. The 2nd appellant is a shareholder and the Managing Director of the Company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State action impairing company rights also impairs shareholder rights qualitatively; cites R.C. Cooper and Bennett Coleman.

holdings.text: There was no valid purchase of the undertaking and taking delivery was unlawful; State Electricity Board directed to redeliver to licensee.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that there was no valid purchase of the undertaking and that taking delivery of the undertaking was unlawful. The State Electricity Board is directed to redeliver the undertaking to the licensee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.6(6) unconstitutional renders purchase and delivery invalid; licence continues until valid payment or interest provision.

Shantilal R. Desai

anchor.surface_text: We hold that S. 6 6  violates the fundamental right under Art. 19 1  g  and 19 1  f  of the 2nd appellant. The undertaking, no doubt, belonged to the 1st appellant, a corporation. Not being a citizen, it has no fundamental right under Art. 19. The 2nd appellant is a shareholder and the Managing Director of the Company.
